perturbation.original_text: NAI retains the right, but not the obligation, to disapprove or remove any advertisements or advertising materials it reasonably deems illegal, inappropriate or otherwise inconsistent with the purposes of the Originating Sites, without the consent of Co-Host.
perturbation.changed_text: NAI retains the right to disapprove or remove any advertisements or advertising materials it deems inappropriate or inconsistent with the purposes of the Originating Sites.
perturbation.explanation: Removing 'illegal' and 'without the consent of Co-Host' allows NAI to remove ads based on subjective criteria, including legal compliance, creating risk. This introduces a **legal contradiction** because if NAI were to allow illegal advertising material without the consent of Co-Host to remain it is a violation of California Business and Professions Code regarding false advertising. Further, it fails to protect consumers from potentially harmful or misleading advertising.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Business and Professions Code Sections 17500 et seq. (False Advertising)

perturbation.original_text: Co-Host agrees that, if notified promptly in writing and given sole control of the defense and all related settlement negotiations, it will defend NAI, its employees, officers and agents, against any claim based on an allegation that (i) advertising materials supplied hereunder infringes a Covered Country patent, copyright, trademark or state trade secret right, or (ii) Co-Host violated any law, statute or ordinance or any governmental or administrative order, rule or regulation with regard to the advertising materials, the operation of the Destination or the manufacture, possession, distribution, use or sale of the Goods.
perturbation.changed_text: Co-Host may defend NAI, its employees, officers and agents, against any claim based on an allegation regarding the advertising materials, the operation of the Destination or the manufacture, possession, distribution, use or sale of the Goods.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'will defend' to 'may defend' and removing the infringement stipulations weakens NAI's protection against legal claims related to the advertising materials, infringing materials and operation of the destination. The removal of 'promptly in writing and given sole control of the defense and all related settlement negotiations' removes a legally required protection. If the Co-Host has other interest they can prioritize, it may not defend NAI, thus violating California's consumer protection laws.

perturbation.original_text: NAI agrees that, if notified promptly in writing and given sole control of the defense and all related settlement negotiations, it will defend Co-Host, its employees, officers and agents against any claim based on an allegation that (i) a Product supplied hereunder infringes a Covered Country patent, copyright, trademark or trade secret right, or (ii) NAI violated any law, statute or ordinance or any governmental or administrative order, rule or regulation with regard to a Product or its manufacturer, possession, use or sale. NAI will pay any resulting costs, damages and attorneys' fees finally awarded by a court, or agreed to in settlement by NAI, with respect to any such claims to the extent of the compensation received under this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: NAI may defend Co-Host, its employees, officers and agents against any claim based on an allegation regarding a Product or its manufacturer, possession, use or sale. NAI will pay any resulting costs, damages and attorneys' fees with respect to any such claims.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'will defend' to 'may defend' removes the obligation for NAI to defend Co-Host. The removal of 'promptly in writing and given sole control of the defense and all related settlement negotiations' removes a legally required protection. Also the removal of 'infringes a Covered Country patent, copyright, trademark or trade secret right, or (ii) NAI violated any law, statute or ordinance or any governmental or administrative order, rule or regulation' gives them no stipulation to what the allegiation refers to, meaning they might defend in some causes, but not others, thus violating consumer protection laws in California.
